questions.text: Most common site of genital TB is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fallopian tube

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Genital tuberculosis (TB) primarily affects the female reproductive system, with the fallopian tubes being the most common site of infection. Tuberculous salpingitis can lead to various complications, including:
  • • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes. Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube. Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum. Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.
  • • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes.
  • • Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube.
  • • Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum.
  • • Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.
  • • These complications can significantly impact fertility, making infertility a common issue in women with genital TB.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Sites of Genital TB:
  • • Option A. Cervix: Less commonly affected.
  • • Option A. Cervix:
  • • Option B. Endometrium: Can be involved, but not as frequently as the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option B. Endometrium:
  • • Option D. Ovary: Also less commonly affected compared to the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option D. Ovary:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fallopian tube is the most common site of genital tuberculosis, leading to significant complications such as salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, and infertility.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Global Hunger Index? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infant Mortality Rate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Global Hunger Index is calculated based on the following indicators:
  • • Till 2014 – following 3 indicators
  • • After 2016, the Global Hunger Index calculation was done using above four indicators, which do not include the infant mortality rate directly.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. U5MR: Because the under-five mortality rate is one of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • A. U5MR:
  • • Option B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting): Because both child wasting and child stunting are part of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting):
  • • Option C. Inadequate food supply: Because, while inadequate food supply can contribute to child undernourishment, it is not directly used as an indicator in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.
  • • Option
  • • C. Inadequate food supply:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Global Hunger Index is calculated using four indicators: child undernourishment, under-five mortality rate, child wasting, and child stunting. The infant mortality rate is not directly included in the calculation.

questions.text: Bubo seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymphogranuloma venereum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3.
  • • A bubo refers to an inflamed, swollen lymph node, often filled with pus. In LGV, this typically presents as inguinal lymphadenitis with pus formation, which is a key characteristic feature.
  • • Another important sexually transmitted disease associated with bubo formation is chancroid.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option B. Syphilis:
  • • Option C. Granuloma inguinale: Also known as donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with subcutaneous nodules in the inguinal region but does not involve lymphadenopathy. These nodules are sometimes referred to as pseudo-bubo because of their superficial similarity to buboes, but they do not have the same pathophysiology.
  • • Option C. Granuloma inguinale:
  • • pseudo-bubo
  • • Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea typically presents with urethral discharge and does not cause bubo formation.
  • • Option D. Gonorrhea:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bubo is a characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and chancroid, involving inflamed, pus-filled lymph nodes, particularly in the inguinal region. ​

questions.text: A post-operative patient who is immobilized develops sudden onset severe calf pain. What is the next investigation to be done? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duplex USG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is duplex ultrasound (USG). The clinical picture suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is a common complication in immobilized, post-operative patients.
  • • Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosing DVT as it combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow and identify any thrombus in the veins.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CT angiography: This is primarily used for pulmonary embolism, not for initial evaluation of suspected DVT.
  • • Option A. CT angiography:
  • • Option C. X-ray: This is not useful for diagnosing DVT, as it does not provide information about the veins or blood flow.
  • • Option C. X-ray:
  • • Option D. MRI: While MRI can visualize DVT, it is not the first-line investigation due to higher cost, longer procedure time, and less availability compared to duplex ultrasound.
  • • Option D. MRI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For post-operative, immobilized patients with sudden onset severe calf pain, suggesting DVT, the next investigation should be a duplex ultrasound, which effectively visualizes the veins and assesses blood flow to confirm the diagnosis. ​

questions.text: A patient presented with ptosis which gets worsened by evening. He was diagnosed to be a case of myasthenia gravis. What is the preferred treatment of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pyridostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and is the mainstay of treatment for myasthenia gravis. It helps increase the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving muscle strength.
  • ➤ Pyridostigmine

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydro-rhodamine test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary to kill certain bacteria and fungi. This condition is most commonly inherited in an X-linked recessive manner due to a defect in the CYBB gene , which encodes a component of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex.
  • • CYBB gene
  • • Patients with CGD typically present with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly affecting the skin, lungs, and lymph nodes. The dihydro-rhodamine (DHR) test, which measures the oxidative burst of neutrophils, is used to diagnose CGD. An abnormal DHR test indicates a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme , confirming the diagnosis of CGD.
  • • dihydro-rhodamine (DHR) test,
  • • defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme
  • • Investigation – NBT and DHR 123 test (flow cytometry)
  • • TOC – Allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; IFN gamma
  • • TOC –
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) : SCID is characterized by a severe defect in both T- and B-lymphocyte systems. It presents very early in life with severe immunodeficiency and is often due to adenosine deaminase deficiency.
  • • Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
  • • Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect : This results in leukocyte adhesion defect type 2 (LAD-2), which involves issues with leukocyte migration due to defective carbohydrate metabolism affecting leukocyte rolling.
  • • Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect
  • • Option D. Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD) : LAD type 1 involves a defect in the CD18 gene affecting leukocyte adhesion and migration, leading to recurrent infections without pus formation and poor wound healing. LAD type 2 involves a defect in the Sialyl Lewis X structure.
  • • Option D. Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Chronic Granulomatous Disease is diagnosed with the DHR test, which reveals defects in the oxidative burst of neutrophils due to NADPH oxidase deficiency.

questions.text: Identify the chest x-ray finding shown below. ( FMGE Jan 2024 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lung collapse

questions.text: Mitochondrial matrix enzyme is? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Citrate synthase

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A woman presented with unilateral pulsatile headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, which is exaggerated on skipping her meals. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Migraine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient presents with a unilateral, pulsatile headache accompanied by photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), and nausea. These are classic features of a migraine.
  • • Additionally, the headache is exacerbated by skipping meals, a known trigger for migraines. Other common triggers include stress, certain foods, and hormonal changes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tension headache: This type of headache is usually bilateral, non-pulsatile, and described as a band-like tightness around the head. It does not typically present with photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea.
  • • Option B. Tension headache:
  • • Option C. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are characterized by severe, unilateral pain around the eye, often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as tearing, nasal congestion, and redness of the eye. They do not typically involve photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea.
  • • Option C. Cluster headache:
  • • Option D. Malingering: This refers to the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms, motivated by external incentives such as avoiding work or obtaining drugs. There is no indication in the question to suggest malingering.
  • • Option D. Malingering:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Migraine is characterized by unilateral, pulsatile headaches accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, and can be triggered by factors such as skipping meals, stress, and certain foods. Recognizing these features is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A dwarf female patient brought to the hospital with a history of primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely placed nipples. What is the most common karyotype associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 45X0

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The presentation of a dwarf female patient with primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is characteristic of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, most commonly represented by the karyotype 45X0. This syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome, characterized by the karyotype 45X0, is the most common chromosomal disorder associated with features such as primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples in females.

questions.text: CT scan given in the image is suggestive of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subdural hematoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped hemorrhage, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH). Subdural hematomas typically occur due to tearing of the bridging veins and are crescent-shaped because they can cross suture lines but are limited by the dural reflections.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Extradural (epidural) hematoma : Usually appears as a biconvex, lenticular shape and does not cross suture lines due to the tight attachment of the dura to the skull at the sutures.
  • • Option A. Extradural (epidural) hematoma
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage : Blood is found within the subarachnoid space, typically around the basal cisterns or within the sulci, and is not crescent-shaped.
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • • Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage : Appears as a hyperdense area within the brain parenchyma and does not have the crescent shape seen here.
  • • Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ A crescent-shaped hemorrhage on a CT scan, especially if it crosses suture lines, is indicative of a subdural hematoma.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Air humidity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a sling psychrometer , which is an instrument used to measure the water content, moisture content, or air humidity .
  • • sling psychrometer
  • • water content, moisture content, or air humidity
  • • A sling psychrometer consists of two thermometers, one of which has a wet bulb (covered in a wet cloth) and the other a dry bulb. By comparing the temperatures of the wet and dry bulbs, the relative humidity can be determined using a psychrometric chart or calculation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Air temperature: While the sling psychrometer does measure air temperature using the dry bulb thermometer, its primary purpose is to measure humidity by comparing the dry and wet bulb temperatures.
  • • Option
  • • A. Air temperature:
  • • Option B. Air velocity: The sling psychrometer is not designed to measure air velocity.
  • • Option
  • • B. Air velocity:
  • • Option D. Cooling air: In the past, the Kata thermometer was used to measure the cooling power of air, but it is now primarily used to assess low air velocity. The sling psychrometer is not designed to measure the cooling effect of air.
  • • Option
  • • D. Cooling air:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sling psychrometer is an instrument used to measure air humidity by comparing the temperatures of a wet bulb and a dry bulb thermometer.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

questions.text: Total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of same reproductive age is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TFR (Total Fertility Rate)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group is referred to as the Total Fertility Rate (TFR).
  • • The following definitions are provided:
  • • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths) GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group
  • • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman
  • • GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan
  • • NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths)
  • • GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because NRR takes into account the mortality of the girls born, not the total number of children born to a woman.
  • • Option
  • • B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate)
  • • Option C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because GFR is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group, not the total number of children born to an individual woman.
  • • Option
  • • C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) -
  • • Option D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because GRR specifically refers to the number of girls born to a woman, not the total number of children born.
  • • Option
  • • D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the measure that represents the total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

questions.text: A teacher presents with the following condition and hoarseness of the voice. Identify.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with early satiety, bleeding and on examination, patient has spleen palpable till umbilicus. WBC count is 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs seen in the peripheral blood smear. What is the diagnosis? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic Myeloid Leukemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The patient presents with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, bleeding, and a significantly elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs in the peripheral smear. These features are characteristic of CML, a type of leukemia where the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells. The presence of immature WBCs (a left shift) and massive splenomegaly are classic signs of CML.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): While AML also involves immature WBCs, it usually presents more acutely and with less pronounced splenomegaly.
  • • Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML):
  • • Diagnosed if – Myeloid blast count >20%; APL (t15:17); CBF (t8:21; t16:16 inversion 16)
  • • Diagnosed if –
  • • Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL): CLL typically presents with a high number of mature lymphocytes rather than immature WBCs .
  • • Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):
  • • immature WBCs
  • • Option D. Sickle cell anemia: This condition is unlikely in a 60-year-old due to autosplenectomy typically occurring by age 3-4, making splenomegaly in this age group highly unlikely. Moreover, the WBC count in sickle cell anemia is not usually elevated to this extent.
  • • Option D. Sickle cell anemia:
  • • autosplenectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CML should be suspected in patients presenting with massive splenomegaly, significantly elevated WBC count, and immature WBCs on peripheral smear. Recognizing these signs can prompt further diagnostic evaluation, including the detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene).
  • ➤ CML ideally Diagnosed as – Blast count <20% + Philadelphia +ve + Left shift in PS (lots of immature WBC)

questions.text: What is the arrangement from near to far of the recti muscles attached towards the limbus? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus

options.label: B
options.text: Superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus

options.label: C
options.text: Medial rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, superior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: Medial rectus, superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus

questions.correct_answer: A. Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a cross-sectional view of the eye with the extraocular muscles labeled along with their distances of attachment from the limbus (sclerocorneal junction). The order of the recti muscles from closest to farthest attachment to the limbus is:
  • • Medial rectus (5.5 mm) Inferior rectus (6.5 mm) Lateral rectus (6.9 mm) Superior rectus (7.7 mm)
  • • Medial rectus (5.5 mm)
  • • Inferior rectus (6.5 mm)
  • • Lateral rectus (6.9 mm)
  • • Superior rectus (7.7 mm)
  • • Remember :
  • • Remember :
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B, C and D are incorrect because they do not list the recti muscles in the correct order from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus.
  • • Option B, C and D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The order of the recti muscles from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus (sclerocorneal junction) is: medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, and superior rectus.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block and suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the first line of management? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20% IV Intralipid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient experienced toxicity due to bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. The first-line treatment for local anesthetic toxicity, including bupivacaine toxicity, is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy). This treatment works by acting as a "lipid sink," which helps to absorb the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules and reduce their toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. IV Epinephrine : Suitable for cardiac arrest but not the first line for local anesthetic toxicity.
  • • Option A. IV Epinephrine
  • • Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate : Used in cases of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity causing ventricular arrhythmias but not for local anesthetic toxicity.
  • • Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate
  • • Option D. IV Dobutamine : Used to treat heart failure and certain types of shock, but not specifically for local anesthetic toxicity
  • • Option D. IV Dobutamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for bupivacaine toxicity is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy).

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.
  • • The key points are:
  • • The key points are:
  • • CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection limit à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen) In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.
  • • CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection limit à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  • • In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  • • CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other
  • • Options:
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
  • • Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.
  • • Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance:
  • • Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.
  • • Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

questions.text: A female had unprotected sexual intercourse and now more than 5 days have passed. She fears getting pregnant. What is the contraceptive of choice in this case? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IUCD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) is an effective form of emergency contraception. Certain types of IUCDs, particularly the copper IUCD, can be used as emergency contraception if inserted within five days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse. They are one of the most effective forms of emergency contraception available.
  • ➤ IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device)

questions.text: A patient presents after 5 days of unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception. What is the method of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IUCD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) is the preferred method for emergency contraception if presented within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse. The IUCD is highly effective and provides long-term contraception, which makes it suitable for women seeking ongoing birth control.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Misoprostol: This is not used for emergency contraception; it is typically used for medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Misoprostol:

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient after receiving haloperidol developed torticollis and dystonia. What will be the best drug in this situation? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Give benzhexol (anticholinergic)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient has developed extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), which are side effects commonly associated with antipsychotic medications like haloperidol. EPS can include dystonia (muscle contractions causing twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures) and torticollis (a type of dystonia involving the neck muscles).
  • • Benzhexol , also known as trihexyphenidyl, is an anticholinergic drug that is effective in treating EPS, including acute dystonic reactions. Anticholinergics help to balance the neurotransmitters in the brain, thereby reducing the symptoms of EPS.
  • • Benzhexol
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Increase haloperidol dose : This would likely worsen the EPS.
  • • Option A. Increase haloperidol dose
  • • Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine : While clozapine has a lower risk of EPS, this is not an immediate treatment for the acute dystonia.
  • • Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine
  • • Option D. Change haloperidol to fluphenazine : Fluphenazine, like haloperidol, is a potent dopamine receptor blocker and would likely exacerbate the EPS.
  • • Option D. Change haloperidol to fluphenazine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The immediate treatment for drug-induced dystonia is the administration of anticholinergic drugs like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl).
  • ➤ The immediate treatment for drug-induced dystonia is the administration of anticholinergic drugs like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl).

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the family cycle.
questions.explanation:

  • • The family cycle consists of the following 6 stages in the correct sequence:
  • • Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child. Extension : From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child. Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.
  • • Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child.
  • • Formation:
  • • Extension : From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child.
  • • Extension
  • • Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home
  • • Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home
  • • Contraction:
  • • Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse
  • • Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.
  • • Dissolution:
  • • The correct sequence is formation, extension, contraction, and finally, dissolution.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution, representing the stages from marriage to the death of the surviving spouse.

questions.text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and pallor. Investigations indicated hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL, increased RDW, increased total iron binding capacity, and low ferritin. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis. What is the likely diagnosis? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and pallor, which are common findings in anemia. The investigations reveal a low hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL, indicating the presence of anemia. The increased red cell distribution width (RDW) suggests anisocytosis, or variation in the size of red blood cells.
  • • The increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and low ferritin levels indicate a deficiency in iron stores. Additionally, the peripheral smear shows microcytosis, which means the presence of small, hypochromic red blood cells. These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hemolytic anemia is incorrect because these patients typically have an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) due to the premature destruction of red blood cells and the release of larger, immature cells into the circulation.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Megaloblastic anemia is incorrect because it is characterized by the presence of large, macrocytic red blood cells, rather than the small, microcytic cells seen in this case.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Sideroblastic anemia is incorrect because it is typically associated with elevated ferritin levels due to increased iron storage, whereas this patient has low ferritin levels.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin, increased RDW, increased TIBC, low ferritin, and the presence of microcytic red blood cells on peripheral smear.

The optimal time to measure NT is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, more specifically between 11 weeks and 13 weeks and 6 days. During this period, the NT measurement is most accurate and predictive. The NT scan involves measuring the clear space in the tissue at the back of the baby's neck.
  • • An absent Nasal Bone (NB) and increased NT measurement both are the marker of Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Nuchal translucency should be measured between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation to effectively screen for chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a diagnostic test for CML? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) FISH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). This test detects the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene produces a protein with abnormal tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the pathogenesis of CML.
  • • Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration : While it can show increased cellularity and myeloid hyperplasia, i.e. help in assessing the extent of disease and marrow involvement but is not definitive for diagnosing CML.
  • • Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration
  • • Option C. LAP score : Low in CML but also low in other conditions, hence not specific.
  • • Option C. LAP score
  • • Option D. Karyotyping : While it can detect chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive compared to FISH for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene.
  • • Option D. Karyotyping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) because it specifically identifies the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy
  • ➤ Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy
  • ➤ Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days. To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery. For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over. Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision. Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion. Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia. Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable. Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

  • ➤ To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.

questions.text: Philadelphia chromosome is caused by translocation of which of the following chromosomes? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 22 and 9

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Philadelphia chromosome, a hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t (9;22) (q34;q11). This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9, creating the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.
  • • t (9;22) (q34;q11).
  • • BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.
  • • The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, which is responsible for the uncontrolled proliferation and survival of myeloid cells in CML. The enhanced tyrosine kinase activity of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein leads to the development of this malignancy.
  • • The specific involvement of the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22 in the translocation can be denoted as t(9q;22q) or t(9;22)(q34;q11), where 'q' represents the long arm, and '34' and '11' represent the specific bands on the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, respectively, where the breakpoints occur.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Philadelphia chromosome, the hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22)(q34;q11). This translocation creates the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase responsible for the development of CML.

questions.text: In seat belt injury, the most commonly involved organ is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Seat belts are known to decrease mortality and prevent head injuries in accidents. However, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries.
  • • Among all the thoracic and abdominal injuries associated with seat belt use, the maximum damage occurs to three organs: mesentery, omentum, and bowel (hollow viscus). This combination of injuries is known as the "seat belt syndrome." Therefore, the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injury is the hollow viscus.
  • • three organs: mesentery, omentum, and bowel (hollow viscus).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A. Liver + Spleen: Although liver and spleen injuries can occur in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly involved organs compared to the hollow viscus.
  • • Option. A. Liver + Spleen:
  • • Option. B. Lungs: While thoracic injuries can be increased due to seat belt use, the lungs are not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries.
  • • Option. B. Lungs:
  • • Option. C. Head of Pancreas: The head of the pancreas is not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries compared to the hollow viscus.
  • • Option. C. Head of Pancreas:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In seat belt injuries, the most commonly involved organ is the hollow viscus (bowel), along with the mesentery and omentum, constituting the "seat belt syndrome." Although seat belts are protective and prevent head injuries, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries, with the hollow viscus being the most frequently affected.

Anatomical Landmarks: The subcostal plane is a horizontal plane that typically lies just below the rib cage. It is an important reference point for dividing the abdomen into regions. questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums. Physical examination reveals fatigue on her skin. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The clinical presentation of fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums, and specific skin manifestations such as perifollicular hemorrhages is characteristic of vitamin C deficiency, known as scurvy.
  • • Scurvy occurs due to inadequate intake of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for collagen synthesis. Collagen is a critical component of connective tissues, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, poor wound healing, and the symptoms observed in scurvy.
  • • Key clinical features of scurvy include:
  • • Key clinical features of scurvy include:
  • • Fatigue : Generalized weakness and tiredness due to impaired energy metabolism. Joint pain : Due to bleeding within joints and weakened connective tissues. Swollen gums : Gingival swelling, bleeding gums, and dental issues. Skin manifestations : Perifollicular hemorrhages and petechiae due to fragile blood vessels.
  • • Fatigue : Generalized weakness and tiredness due to impaired energy metabolism.
  • • Fatigue
  • • Joint pain : Due to bleeding within joints and weakened connective tissues.
  • • Joint pain
  • • Swollen gums : Gingival swelling, bleeding gums, and dental issues.
  • • Swollen gums
  • • Skin manifestations : Perifollicular hemorrhages and petechiae due to fragile blood vessels.
  • • Skin manifestations
  • • The treatment for scurvy is supplementation with vitamin C, which will help restore collagen synthesis and resolve the symptoms.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Vitamin D : Deficiency in vitamin D typically presents with symptoms related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, rather than the symptoms described here. Option C. Vitamin A : Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness), immune function, and skin health. It does not typically cause the symptoms described. Option D. Vitamin E : Vitamin E deficiency is rare and usually presents with neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia, not with the symptoms described in this case.
  • • Option A. Vitamin D : Deficiency in vitamin D typically presents with symptoms related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, rather than the symptoms described here.
  • • Option A. Vitamin D
  • • Option C. Vitamin A : Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness), immune function, and skin health. It does not typically cause the symptoms described.
  • • Option C. Vitamin A
  • • Option D. Vitamin E : Vitamin E deficiency is rare and usually presents with neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia, not with the symptoms described in this case.
  • • Option D. Vitamin E

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums, and specific skin manifestations. Treatment is supplementation with vitamin C.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs can increase glucose excretion in urine? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor .
  • • an SGLT2 inhibitor
  • • Drugs in this class (such as empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and dapagliflozin) inhibit the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glycosuria). This helps lower blood glucose levels.
  • • Other Options:

questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to the hospital with blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nifedipine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In managing hypertension in a pregnant patient with a history of bronchial asthma, the choice of antihypertensive medication is critical due to the contraindications of certain drug classes in both pregnancy and asthma.
  • • Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is considered safe in pregnancy and does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it the preferred choice for hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with asthma.
  • • Nifedipine
  • • Nicardipine, another calcium channel blocker, can also be used, especially in IV form, but nifedipine is often chosen due to its safety profile and efficacy.
  • • Nicardipine,
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Oral Labetalol and Option C. IV Labetalol : Contraindicated in asthma due to bronchoconstriction. These drugs can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction, making them unsuitable for patients with asthma.
  • • Option B. Oral Labetalol
  • • Option C. IV Labetalol
  • • Option D. Ramipril : ACE inhibitors like Ramipril are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal toxicity, including renal damage and oligohydramnios
  • • Option D. Ramipril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ For hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with bronchial asthma, nifedipine is the preferred drug due to its safety in pregnancy and lack of bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male presented to the emergency with sudden onset of abdominal pain radiating to the back, which is aggravated on lying down. Serum amylase and lipase levels are elevated. Which of the following should be avoided in managing the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition

options.label: D
options.text: Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Infusion of 5% Dextrose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of acute pancreatitis, a condition confirmed by elevated serum amylase and lipase levels.
  • • Infusion of 5% Dextrose : This should be avoided in managing acute pancreatitis. Patients often experience hyperglycemia, and the administration of dextrose could worsen this condition. Preferred intravenous fluids for rehydration and initial resuscitation in acute pancreatitis are normal saline (NS) or Ringer's lactate (RL).
  • • Infusion of 5% Dextrose
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation : Keeping the patient NPO (nothing by mouth) is crucial to avoid stimulating the pancreas and exacerbating the condition.
  • • Option A. NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation
  • • Option C. Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition : This is correct. Early enteral nutrition is preferred over total parenteral nutrition as it helps maintain gut integrity and reduce the risk of infection.
  • • Option C. Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition
  • • Option D. Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis : This is also correct. For mild cases, early reintroduction of oral feeding is beneficial.
  • • Option D. Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the infusion of 5% dextrose due to the risk of exacerbating hyperglycemia.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. Which of the following conditions is responsible? ( FMGE Jan 2024)

  • • Option C. Hemiballismus: This condition involves violent, involuntary movements of one side of the body, not the flapping tremors associated with asterixis.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with infertility, and he has chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. What is the likely disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kartagener's syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kartagener's syndrome, a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia, is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.
  • • Infertility in males is also a common feature due to the dysfunction of cilia and flagella, leading to impaired sperm motility.
  • • Situs inversus is a condition where the major visceral organs are mirrored from their normal positions, often seen in Kartagener's syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cystic fibrosis : While patients with cystic fibrosis may also present with sinusitis, infertility, and bronchiectasis, they do not typically have situs inversus, which is specific to Kartagener's syndrome.
  • • Option B. Cystic fibrosis
  • • Option C. Mucoviscidosis : This is another term for cystic fibrosis, and thus the same reasoning applies as above.
  • • Option C. Mucoviscidosis
  • • Option D. Klinefelter syndrome : This genetic disorder can present with infertility but does not include chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, or situs inversus.
  • • Option D. Klinefelter syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus, and is associated with infertility in males due to primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: Radioactive tracer used in PET scans:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) F18-Deoxyglucose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The most commonly used radioactive tracer in PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans is F18-deoxyglucose (FDG) . FDG is a glucose analog that gets taken up by metabolically active cells, including cancer cells, making it very useful for identifying areas of high metabolic activity such as tumors and sites of inflammation.
  • • F18-deoxyglucose (FDG)
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Tc99m (Technetium-99m) : Used in certain SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) scans, not PET scans. It is used for a variety of diagnostic imaging purposes, including cardiac and skeletal imaging.
  • • Option B. Tc99m (Technetium-99m)
  • • Option C. I131 (Iodine-131) : Used primarily for radioactive iodine ablation therapy in thyroid cancer and hyperthyroidism, not for PET scans.
  • • Option C. I131 (Iodine-131)
  • • Option D. Co60 (Cobalt-60) : Used in external beam radiotherapy for cancer treatment, not for PET scans.
  • • Option D. Co60 (Cobalt-60)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ F18-deoxyglucose (FDG) is the primary radioactive tracer used in PET scans for detecting areas of high metabolic activity, such as tumors and inflammatory sites.
  • ➤ F18-deoxyglucose (FDG)

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.
  • • anterior nucleus
  • • cooling
  • • posterior nucleus
  • • warming
  • • This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.
  • • Option B. Basal ganglia:
  • • Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.
  • • Option C. Thalamus:
  • • Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.
  • • Option D. Limbic system:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a genital lesion as shown below. What is the best treatment option for her? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cryotherapy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a genital wart, which is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically referred to as condyloma acuminata. In the context of pregnancy, the treatment options for genital warts must be chosen with caution to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.
  • • Treatment Considerations in Pregnancy:
  • • Cryotherapy: This method involves freezing the wart with liquid nitrogen, which is a safe and effective treatment for genital warts during pregnancy. It is widely preferred due to its safety profile and effectiveness. Trichloroacetic acid is another safe option during pregnancy for treating genital warts.
  • • Cryotherapy: This method involves freezing the wart with liquid nitrogen, which is a safe and effective treatment for genital warts during pregnancy. It is widely preferred due to its safety profile and effectiveness.
  • • Trichloroacetic acid is another safe option during pregnancy for treating genital warts.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Surgical excision: Though safe, it is not the first-line treatment in most cases unless the warts are extensive.
  • • Option A. Surgical excision:
  • • Option B. Podophyllin: Not recommended during pregnancy due to safety concerns.
  • • Option B. Podophyllin:
  • • Option C. 5% imiquimod: Also avoided during pregnancy due to safety concerns.
  • • Option C. 5% imiquimod:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best treatment option for genital warts in a pregnant woman is cryotherapy, as it is safe and effective during pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the shown congenital anomaly in which the intestinal loops are present outside the abdominal cavity covered by amniotic membrane. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a congenital anomaly known as omphalocele. This condition is characterized by the presence of intestinal loops and sometimes other abdominal organs outside the abdominal cavity. These organs are covered by a transparent sac composed of the amniotic membrane, peritoneum, and Wharton's jelly.
  • • Omphalocele Characteristics: In omphalocele, the herniated organs protrude through the umbilical ring and are covered by the amniotic membrane. This condition is associated with various other congenital anomalies and syndromes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Gastroschisis : This is incorrect. In gastroschisis, the intestines protrude through a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilical cord, without any covering membrane. The exposed intestines are directly exposed to the amniotic fluid, which distinguishes it from omphalocele.
  • • Option A. Gastroschisis
  • • Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst : This is incorrect. While an omphalocele can be associated with various anomalies, the specific mention of an enteric cyst is not a standard characteristic of typical omphalocele presentations.
  • • Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst
  • • Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. Gastroschisis involves exposed intestines without a covering membrane. The presence of an enteric cyst does not align with the typical presentation of gastroschisis.
  • • Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital anomaly where the intestines and possibly other organs protrude through the umbilical ring, covered by the amniotic membrane. This differentiates it from gastroschisis, where the intestines are exposed without a covering membrane.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman discovers a well-defined, mobile and rubbery breast lump measuring 2.5 x 6 cm on self-examination. The lesion is painless and has been stable over several months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described characteristics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given scenario describes a young female with a well-defined, mobile lump in the breast, which is characteristic of a breast mouse or fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors that typically present as freely mobile masses in young women. They consist of an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma. Depending on the arrangement of the fibrous tissue, fibroadenomas can be classified as pericanalicular or intracanalicular subtypes. Notably, the use of the immunosuppressive drug cyclosporine has been associated with an increased risk of developing fibroadenomas.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ), Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma, and Option D. Intraductal papilloma are all malignant or precancerous lesions that would typically present with additional signs such as skin dimpling, nipple retraction, or ulceration, rather than as a mobile, painless lump in a young woman.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option
  • • D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibroadenomas are the most common cause of benign, mobile breast lumps in young women. They are characterized by an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma and may be associated with the use of cyclosporine.
  • ➤ may be associated with the use of cyclosporine.

questions.text: Identify the marked chamber? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left atrium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The radiological image shows a transverse section of the heart.
  • • In a CT scan taken with the patient lying supine, the right atrium and right ventricle will be seen on the front side, while the left atrium and left ventricle will be at the back. The base (posterior surface) of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and the right atrium (one-third).
  • • In the image, the vertebra is at the back, and the aorta is on the left side in front of the vertebra. The esophagus is closely related to the base of the heart, particularly the left atrium. The chamber marked in the question is the one just in front of the esophagus is the left atrium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Right atrium: The right atrium is towards the right side and forms the right border of the heart in this view.
  • • Option A. Right atrium:
  • • Option C. Right ventricle: The right ventricle lies on the front side along with the right atrium. It forms the sternocostal surface of the heart. The marked chamber is at the back, so it cannot be the right ventricle.
  • • Option C. Right ventricle:
  • • Option D. Left ventricle : The left ventricle lies next to the left atrium at the back in this transverse section. However, the marked chamber is the one closest to the esophagus, which is the left atrium, not the left ventricle.
  • • Option D. Left ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a transverse CT section of the heart, the right atrium and ventricle are seen anteriorly, while the left atrium and ventricle are seen posteriorly.

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The histopathological image shows a characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic (darkly stained) cells, which is indicative of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).
  • • Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis. It is characterized by the presence of basaloid cells arranged in a palisading pattern, with peripheral cells exhibiting hyperchromatic nuclei and a paler center.
  • • The key features that suggest this image represents basal cell carcinoma include:
  • • Palisading arrangement: The tumor cells are arranged in a distinct palisading pattern, with peripheral cells arranged in a radial fashion around the center. Hyperchromatic cells: The cells at the periphery of the tumor nests have darkly stained (hyperchromatic) nuclei, which is a characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma. Lack of keratinization: Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, there is no evidence of keratinization (formation of keratin pearls) in this image.
  • • Palisading arrangement: The tumor cells are arranged in a distinct palisading pattern, with peripheral cells arranged in a radial fashion around the center.
  • • Hyperchromatic cells: The cells at the periphery of the tumor nests have darkly stained (hyperchromatic) nuclei, which is a characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma.
  • • Lack of keratinization: Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, there is no evidence of keratinization (formation of keratin pearls) in this image.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer typically shows evidence of keratinization and does not exhibit the distinctive palisading pattern observed in the image.
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma:
  • • Option C. Adenocarcinoma: This is a type of cancer that originates from glandular epithelial cells and is not typically found in the skin.
  • • Option C. Adenocarcinoma:
  • • Option D. Malignant melanoma: This is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes and typically exhibits a different morphological appearance, with the presence of melanin pigment and atypical melanocytes.
  • • Option D. Malignant melanoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic basaloid cells is a hallmark feature of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis.

questions.text: A high dose of folic acid should be given pre-conceptionally in women with? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Poorly controlled diabetes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A high dose of folic acid is recommended pre-conceptionally for women who are at a higher risk of neural tube defects. This includes women with poorly controlled diabetes, which is associated with an increased risk of congenital abnormalities, including neural tube defects. A high dose of folic acid (4 to 5 mg daily) should be started at least three months before conception to reduce this risk and to be given till 16 weeks of pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia: The preventive strategy for women with a history of preeclampsia includes the use of low-dose aspirin (Ecosprin), not high-dose folic acid.
  • • Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia:
  • • Option B. Previous preterm delivery: Management includes progesterone supplementation or considering a cervical cerclage in cases of cervical insufficiency, rather than high-dose folic acid.
  • • Option B. Previous preterm delivery:
  • • Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While folic acid is important in hemoglobinopathies, the primary concern in sickle cell anemia is maintaining adequate folic acid levels due to increased hemolysis, but it is not specifically indicated at high doses for pre-conception.
  • • Option C. Sickle cell anemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Women with poorly controlled diabetes, epileptics, should receive a high dose of folic acid pre-conceptionally to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

questions.text: All of the following are true about neutrophil extracellular trap except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phagocytosis is enhanced

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phagocytosis is enhanced: This statement is incorrect. NET formation does not directly enhance phagocytosis. Instead, it is a distinct mechanism where the neutrophil traps and kills pathogens extracellularly, without engulfing them through phagocytosis.
  • • Phagocytosis is enhanced:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are a defense mechanism employed by neutrophils to trap and kill extracellular pathogens. During NET formation, neutrophils undergo a process called NETosis, which involves chromatin decondensation and the release of DNA along with antibacterial enzymes into the extracellular space. This forms a mesh-like structure that can trap and kill bacteria.
  • • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs)
  • • Option A: Induced by sepsis: True. NETs are induced by various stimuli, including sepsis. In septicemia-like conditions, the presence of pathogens triggers the formation of NETs as a response to the infection.
  • • Option A: Induced by sepsis:
  • • Option C: Higher risk of SLE: True. NET formation also has some negative consequences. The exposure of nuclear antigens during NETosis can lead to an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The nuclear antigens released during NET formation can be recognized as "self" by the immune system, leading to the production of autoantibodies and the development of SLE.
  • • Option C: Higher risk of SLE:
  • • Option D: Affected cell does not survive: True. In NET formation, the neutrophil undergoes a form of cell death called NETotic cell death. The affected neutrophil does not survive the process of NETosis, as it involves the release of its cellular contents, including DNA and enzymes. This process is sometimes referred to as "beneficial suicide" because the neutrophil sacrifices itself to create the extracellular trap that can capture and kill pathogens.
  • • Option D: Affected cell does not survive:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neutrophil extracellular traps are induced by sepsis, increase the risk of developing SLE due to exposure of nuclear antigens, and result in the death of the affected neutrophil, but they do not enhance phagocytosis.

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.
  • • Option B. Air embolism:
  • • Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.
  • • Option C. Atelectasis:
  • • Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Myocardial Infarction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.
  • ➤ Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.
  • ➤ Note -

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.
  • • Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.
  • • While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.
  • • Pernicious malaria - (due to heavy parasitization)
  • • Pernicious malaria - (due to heavy parasitization)
  • • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs
  • • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

questions.text: In measurement of rifled barrel weapon, caliber depends on: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: A. Distance between two opposite lands
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Distance between two opposite lands

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a rifled firearm, the barrel's interior has alternating projecting parts called lands and the adjacent parts called grooves. The caliber of a rifled barrel weapon is defined as the distance between two opposite lands, which represents the diameter of the rifled firearm.
  • • This is different from a smooth bore firearm, where the diameter is simply called the bore, as there are no lands or grooves present.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. B. Distance between two opposite grooves: The distance between two opposite grooves is not used to determine the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon. The caliber is measured between the lands, not the grooves.
  • • Option. B. Distance between two opposite grooves:
  • • Option. C. Number of lead pellets : The number of lead pellets is not related to the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon. Lead pellets are typically associated with shotguns, which have smooth bore barrels.
  • • Option. C. Number of lead pellets
  • • Option. D. Mass and velocity : While the mass and velocity of a projectile are important factors in the performance of a firearm, they do not determine the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon.
  • • Option. D. Mass and velocity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The caliber of a rifled barrel weapon is determined by the distance between two opposite lands, which represents the diameter of the rifled firearm's barrel. This is different from a smooth bore firearm, where the diameter is simply called the bore.

questions.text: Which virus outbreak occurred in Kerala following consumption of date palm sap? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

Date palm sap, which is a popular drink in the region, can become contaminated with bat secretions containing the Nipah virus when bats feed on the sap. Consumption of this contaminated sap led to the Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala.

It is linked to the consumption of litchis on an empty stomach by children, which can lead to severe hypoglycemia and death due to the generation of methylenecyclopropylglycine (MCPG).
  • • Option
  • • C. Litchi Virus Disease,
  • • empty stomach by children,
  • • severe hypoglycemia and death
  • • Option D. West Nile Fever, transmitted by the Culex pipiens mosquito, has been reported in Kerala.
  • • Option
  • • D. West Nile Fever,
  • • Note - Although a single case of Ebola virus was reported at the Delhi International Airport, it is not related to the Kerala outbreak caused by the consumption of date palm sap.
  • • Note

Educational Objective:
